utterances: Wow.
Perpendicular to the hour hand?
How many times a day?
Well, let's do it for an hour.

You know we're starting at noon, say, and they are perpendicular, and then as you work around, and they'll be perpendicular again a little after 1:00, but they will have been perpendicular once between that, too.
So--uh-huh.
So let's say how many times do they connect between midnight and midnight?
That would be, I believe, 11 times, and then you have to double that because--for that time in between, so up to 22.
And then because we're going 24 hours a day, I'm saying 44.
That's what Ed Green said, and he's in the mathematics and computer science department at North Georgia College and State University.
You're pretty amazing, Will.
And finally, I guess, I mean, do you feel like when you go on the world puzzle championships, you're kind of--your bag is increased every time you come back?
Yes, it does.
I always bring back books, puzzles, everything.
Absolutely.
Well, it's been a real pleasure having you on the program today, Will, and to talk to you today.
So thanks a lot for all the fun you've given us.
Well, this was a lot of fun.
OK.
Take care, hon.
You, too.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Liane Hansen.
And I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We've been talking periodically with a group of undecided voters from across the country.
With Iowa and New Hampshire behind us, we thought we'd see if anything has changed their minds.
Let's start with one of our votes who will be heading to the polls on Super Tuesday, that is February 5th, when 23 states will hold primaries or caucuses.
Let's listen to what she told me about herself back in November.
(Soundbite of archived recording)
My name is Shannon Jackson.
I'm from San Diego, California.
I am a Democrat.
And (unintelligible) voting for Hillary Clinton.
And what do you like about Hillary Clinton?
I don't know.
She just seems to have kind of gusto and kind of knows what she wants and she's kind of grabbing the bull by the horns.
And I kind of like that.
So Shannon is back with us now.
And Shannon, you were undecided back then?
You kind of liked Hillary Clinton?
Yes.
And now, after New Hampshire, where are you?
I don't know.
I think I'm - maybe a little bit more undecided than when I was then now.
Because I think - I don't know, you know.
I'm just very excited about what's going on.
So wait, what makes you more undecided now?
Well, I think originally when there was kind of this buzz about Obama, I think that I was very excited about him then.
But I didn't know if the whole country was ready for that.
So I kind of went towards Hillary Clinton, thinking that maybe she was more electable.
But after what I saw in Iowa, I started to kind of go back a little bit and maybe that people actually do, you know, maybe Obama could actually, you know, win this nomination.
So then, but last night there was Clinton again.
And you know, so it's kind of difficult.
I don't know.
It's very exciting.
You're in the Navy.
Yes.
And you told me that government spending and the military are the most important things to you when you vote.
Do you still feel that way?
And if so, which candidate is more attractive on those issues?
I think I do still feel that way.
And that's one thing that I think maybe is affecting how I think about who I going to vote for.

I'm not really sure there's any candidate at this point that's kind of, you know, saying anything that I want to hear about government spending or, you know, what we're going to do about Iraq, what we're going to do about the military.
So I think maybe that's one thing that's kind of keeping me from making a decision either way.
So what will you be looking for in the weeks leading up to February 5th, Super Tuesday?
Inside, the congregation sings of forgiveness and redemption and hope, but Reverend Arthur Suggs says the community has to go beyond words.
The sounds of a symphony of truck horns, this past weekend, in Detroit.
Thanks.
Thanks very much, Rebecca.
We've all become accustomed to produce that is available year round.
In the winter months, 90 percent of the tomatoes in your supermarket or on your hamburger come from Florida.
And that business is ground zero for modern day slavery.
Some tomato pickers here work seven days a week in debt bondage to their employers.
Amy Bennett Williams is a senior writer for the Fort Myers News Press.
She's been breaking stories on this issue for years now and she joins us here in the studios of WGCU in Fort Myers.
Thanks very much for coming in.
Oh, thanks for asking me.
And if have questions about how this works, what's being done about it, and we'd especially like to hear from those of you who live with this outrage here in Florida, give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email us talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our Web site, that's at npr.org click on TALK OF THE NATION.
And, Amy, when we say slavery, the image that comes to most of our minds is, you know Antebellum cotton plantations.
Is this the same kind of thing?
MS.
WILLIAMS: Not entirely.
They're not cotton plantations.
They are sometimes citrus groves or tomato fields.
The most recent high profile case was of a group of 12 or so men who were taken by their captors to harvest tomatoes in the fields of South Florida.
What it does have in common with the Antebellum pictures is that, certainly, a lot of these cases involve debt bondage.
But this particular case involved all of the mechanisms of restraint and abuse that we associate with pre-Civil War slavery (unintelligible).
Chains, that sort of thing?
MS.
WILLIAMS: Yeah.
Chains, they were shackled to posts.
They were beaten.
They were locked up at night in quarters, essentially U-haul trucks with no bathrooms, so they had to use the corners.
Sometimes, their captors made them fight each other - all of - and certainly this, coupled with an insurmountable debt.
The way that they escaped, finally, was one man noticed that the truck had a little piece of rust and he could see some light through it.
So he punched his way out, squeezed out and made his way to safety.
And were the employers arrested?
MS.
WILLIAMS: Yes, they certainly were.
And they were prosecuted in federal court here.
They were sentenced less than a year ago in December.
And they are all facing pretty significant jail terms.
Of course, there's no parole when it's a federal case, so they're gone.
And the assistant U.S.
attorney who prosecuted them told me, just this morning, that he has another 10 investigations he's working on.
That's the man named Doug Molloy.
And when we said this is ground zero for slavery type cases, that's a quote from him.
MS. WILLIAMS: Yes.
Yes.
And when you say they were captured, where?
Are these people from Central America?
MS.
WILLIAMS: They're from - mostly, they're from Mexico and Central America, although, there are many slavery cases that involve U.S.
citizens as well.
It really runs the spectrum.
The common character, though, is power and abuse.
And the people who hold these people captives have some way of maintaining their power over them whether it's with debt bondage or ropes or drugs and alcohol.
They - it's the balance of power.
And they're smuggled into the country the same way illegal immigrants are smuggled into the country, across the border?
Not necessarily.
Yes - in some cases, yes.
But in others, for example, people will go under bridges and to bus stations and recruit homeless people.
So people who could be Americans, too?
Vulnerable - yes.
Certainly - as I said, a couple of these cases had involved American-born citizens.
But what they are is vulnerable in one way or another.
And how - we think of - obviously, the tomato growing, and the tomato picking industries are quite big here in the state of Florida.
How much a part of it is this?
I - no one knows.
There are no statistics.
I heard an estimate today that perhaps five percent of the labor force is held in some kind of slavery conditions.
But slaves don't report, themselves, and for every case that is prosecuted, it's more than likely, Doug Molloy estimates, that there are other cases that will never see the light of day.
